content: Several tax options have been proposed to finance health care reform, including restricting itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers, modifying the tax exclusion for employer-provided health care, increasing taxes on alcoholic beverages, and imposing an excise tax on non-diet sweetened beverages. The House Ways and Means Committee has suggested financing the reform through a surtax on high-income individuals, which was passed by the House on November 14, 2009. The House passed H.R. 3962 on November 14, 2009, which was based on H.R. 3200. The Senate passed H.R. 3590 on December 24, 2009, with revenue-raising provisions similar to S. 1796. President Obama proposed changes to H.R. 3590, including delaying the tax on high-cost employer plans to 2018 and raising the exemption threshold. The new plan also broadens the proposed increase of the Medicare HI tax for high-income individuals. The House passed H.R. 3590, which proposed increasing the Medicare HI tax for high-income households and adding a 3.8% tax on unearned income. The President signed H.R. 3590 on March 23, along with H.R. 4872 on March 30. The tax proposals varied in their effects on behavior and income distribution. The tax proposals in H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872 varied in their effects on behavior and income distribution. The distributional analysis in the report shows that tax changes can be progressive for high-income taxpayers and regressive for lower-income taxpayers. Excise taxes tend to fall more heavily on lower-income classes. The revenue raisers proposed in the House and Senate bills, along with President Obama's proposals, are reviewed in this report. The main revenue raiser in the final legislation is the increased Medicare tax, accounting for 48% of revenue over FY2010-FY2019. Other significant revenue raisers include a fee on health insurance providers, a "Cadillac" tax on high-value employer health insurance plans, and a fee on branded drugs. The largest revenue raiser in the final legislation is the increased Medicare tax, accounting for 48% of revenue over FY2010-FY2019. Other significant provisions include fees on health insurance providers, a "Cadillac" tax on high-value employer health insurance plans, and a fee on branded drugs. Additional provisions account for about 90% of revenues, with shares changing over time due to delays and expirations. In 2019, the Medicare tax is 44% of the total, while the Cadillac tax is 22%. The House Ways and Means Committee announced revenue- and tax-related provisions to fund health care reform, including a tax on high-income individuals. Legislation like H.R. 3200 and H.R. 3962 included modifications to proposals and new revenue raisers. H.R. 3962, passed in November 2009, involved revisions to the surtax on high-income taxpayers and additional revenue raisers. The initial proposal in H.R. 3200 aimed to fund health care reform by generating $583.1 billion for FY2010-FY2014, with $543.9 billion coming from a surtax on individual taxpayers. The surtax would be based on adjusted gross income, with rates ranging from 1% to 5.4% for different income levels. There was also a provision to raise $8 billion by aligning the definition of medical expenses for health savings accounts with itemized deductions for health. The proposal in H.R. 3962 included revenue raisers related to international taxation and tax evasion, such as a delay in the revised allocation of interest for the foreign tax credit, a provision to address tax sheltering by corporations, and an expansion of the definition of dependents for certain health-related tax purposes. These measures were estimated to raise billions of dollars, with the most recent addition being a 5.4% surtax on incomes over $1 million for joint filers. H.R. 3962 imposed a 5.4% surtax on incomes over $1 million for joint filers and half that amount for single taxpayers, raising $460.5 billion over FY2010-FY2014. It also included revenue raisers related to international taxation and tax evasion, projected to raise billions of dollars. Additionally, the bill had restrictions on health-related tax provisions. H.R. 3962 includes restrictions on health-related tax provisions such as limiting health flexible spending arrangements, increasing penalties for nonqualified distributions from health savings accounts, disallowing deductions for subsidies related to Medicare Part D, imposing an excise tax on medical devices, and requiring information reporting on payments to corporations. The Senate Finance Committee proposal includes health benefits for spouses and dependents, fees on insured and self-insured health plans, and a provision to exclude Indian Tribe health benefits from gross income. The proposal also includes a tax on the sale of medical devices and other provisions. The original surtax on high-income individuals would target the top 1.2% of taxpayers. The surtax proposal in H.R. 3962 would affect 0.3% of taxpayers, with concerns raised about its impact on small businesses and entrepreneurship. Only about 4% of businesses would be affected initially, with 1.2% of unincorporated businesses paying the revised surtax. Higher-income individuals would be more affected due to their larger share of income. The concentration of income at higher levels is evident, with individuals earning over $1 million accounting for 15.1% of adjusted gross income but only 0.2% of returns. Business income is more concentrated in higher-income levels. Labor income makes up three-quarters of overall income, while passive capital income, pensions, and business income account for the rest. In the top 1%, labor income is less than half of total income. Returns with income over $1 million contribute 7.5% of total proprietorship income. For partnerships and Subchapter S firms, those with income over $1 million account for 49% of net income. Taxpayers at the top tax rate are responsible for 61% of business flow-through income. Some income in partnerships and proprietorships may come from passive income and tax shelters. According to IRS data, almost 85% of partnership income is in limited liability companies or limited partnerships, with high-income taxpayers only accounting for 46% of active positive business income. The Tax Policy Center found that only 22.8% of returns affected by the surtax had business income that was more than half of total income, suggesting that much of this income is passive investment income. The majority of partnership income comes from finance, real estate, oil and gas extraction, and services like doctors and lawyers. About 8% of income is from real estate and oil and gas, 19% from finance and insurance, with most of that from securities and investment firms. 15% is from professional services, mainly legal services, and 5% from health services, including physicians and dentists. This data suggests that a significant portion of small business income is from passive investments and professions like stockbrokers, lawyers, and doctors. There is no need for a permanent policy to create jobs. The economy creates its own jobs over time. Excluding flow through income from the top 1% would sacrifice revenue, but excluding passive income and income from certain sectors could minimize the loss.
